_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Diffusion Tank for relief valve discharge
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Compressors, Condensors, Accumulator, Receiver, Piping, Diffusion Tank, Air Units, Chillers, Cooling Towers, Heat Exchangers, Ventilation, Silos, Ammonia Detectors, Compressor Safeties, Valves

_emerg_resp.CoordinatingAgencyName: Onondaga Co. Dept. of Emergency Mgt

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Byrne DeWitt facility manufactures extended shelf life milks, creams, and other dairy and related products.  As part of its manufacturing operation, Byrne DeWitt operates an anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system which is used for process cooling.  In early 2025 Byrne DeWitt completed a project that included expanding the ammonia system to cover a new Processing area. Coverage extended to 4 new milk silos, a new air handler and a new glycol exchanger. 
These changes included the addition of 2,002 pounds of anhydrous ammonia bringing the total amount in the upgraded system to approximately 21,665 pounds.  

Since the quantity of anhydrous ammonia at Byrne DeWitt exceeds the Risk Management Plan (RMP) threshold of 10,000 lbs., the facility has prepared this RMP to meet the requirements of Section 112(r)(7) of the Clean Air Act (CAA) pursuant to the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) regulations contained in Part 68 of Code 40 of the Federal Regulations (40 CFR Part 68), Sections 68.1-68.220, Accidental Release Prevention Provisions.  The facility also has a Process Safety Management (PSM) plan in place to meet the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) requirements of 29 CFR1910.119.  The RMP and PSM plans complement one another to meet both sets of regulations.

Given the larger volume of ammonia in the system with the recent plant expansion, the accidental release modeling was updated as required by 40 CFR 68.  The modeling did not drive the toxic endpoint distance of an accidental release to more than two times the distance of the last RMP submission (0.8 to 1.5 miles).  Byrne DeWitt performed a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) Review, triggering a revision to this analysis and the need to resubmit the RMP update per 68.190(b)5.  The PHA did not result in any significant changes to Byrne DeWitt's anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system's safety systems, operation or maintenance program.
 
Byrne DeWitt goes to great lengths to mainta

in its ammonia refrigeration system to prevent releases.  An inspection and maintenance program is in place that includes daily, monthly, quarterly, semi-annual and annual activities to monitor and maintain the system by trained personnel in an effort to ensure proper, safe operation.  Byrne DeWitt also performs periodic non-destructive examination of vessels and piping systems to ensure mechanical integrity. The last full exam was completed in May 2020 and the next one is scheduled for May 2025.

Various safeguards and detection measures are in place to identify a potential problem and to minimize the effect of one should it occur.  The ammonia refrigeration system is located in an enclosed and secured room. The facility is equipped with ammonia detection sensors in critical locations to detect ammonia leaks.  Refrigeration system alarms (both visual and audible) are available for high pressure, high temperature and both high and low ammonia levels. Pressure relief valves are in place to relieve the system in the event of an over-pressurization in order to prevent a catastrophic failure.  All of the pressure relief valves are vented external to the building and most are directed through a water diffusion tank to further mitigate an ammonia release.  Additional pressure relief valves have been added as the ammonia refrigeration system has expanded to provide appropriate protection.

Byrne DeWitt provides specific training on the ammonia system to site Maintenance personnel involved in maintaining the ammonia refrigeration system.  Awareness training on the hazards of anhydrous ammonia is provided to all site personnel.  Byrne DeWitt has an Emergency Action Plan in place to provide guidance in the event of a release.  All employees and site workers receive training on the plan and drills are held to evaluate its effectiveness.  Byrne DeWitt works with local emergency response personnel to ensure that they are familiar with the key features of the facility, including

the ammonia refrigeration system.  Representatives from the local fire department, local Haz Mat team and County Department of Emergency Management are invited to the site annually to accommodate for changes in support service staffing and to maintain familiarity and accommodate for local jurisdiction code requirements.

Byrne DeWitt strives to promote safety and awareness of the risks associated with anhydrous ammonia and will work to continually improve the RMP/PSM program and the safety of its ammonia refrigeration system.
